DIV1.P: THE DRAGON OF WANTLEY. A BURLESQUE OPERA. The MUSICK By Mr. JOHN FREDERICK LAMPE, And Performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL in Govent-Garden. Moderniz'd from the OLD BALLAD after the Italian Manner, by Sig. CARINI.
LONDON: Printed for J. SHUCKBURGH, at the Sun near the Inner-Temple-Gate in Fleet-street, 1737. (Price Six-pence.)

DIV1.HEAD: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
DIV1.P: SCENE that Part of Yorkshire near Rotheram.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS.
SP.L: FLY, Neighbours, fly,
The Dragon's nigh,
Save your Lives and fly;
Away, away,
For if you stay,
Sure as a Gun you die. Fly, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: What wretched Havock does this Dragon make!
He sticks at nothing for his Belly's Sake:
Feeding but makes his Appetite the stronger,
He'll eat us all, if he 'bides here much longer!

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS.
SP.L: Houses and Churches,
To Him are Geese and Turkies.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: O Father! Father! as our noble 'Squire
Was sate at Breakfast by his Parlour Fire,
With Wife and Children, all in pleasant Tattle,
The Table shook, the Cups began to rattle;
A dismal Noise was heard within the Hall,
Away they flew, the Dragon scar'd them all:
He drank up all their Coffee at a Sup,
And next devour'd their Toast and Butter up.

LG.L: But to hear the Children mutter,
When they'd lost their Toast and Butter,
And to see my Lady moan,
Oh! 'twould melt a Heart of Stone.
There the Maids and Mistress jangling,
Oh! 'twould make one's Heart to ake. But to hear, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub
SP.L: This Dragon very modish, sure, and nice is:
What shall we do in this diast'rous Crisis?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: A Thought, to quell him, comes into my Head;
No way more proper than to kill him dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: O Miracle of Wisdom! rare Suggestion!
But how, or who to do it, that's the Question.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Not far from hence there lives a valiant Knight,
A Man of Prowess great, and mickle Might:
He has done Deeds St. George himself might brag on;

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: This very Man is he shall kill the Dragon.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: He's a Man ev'ry Inch, I assure you,
There's none can from Danger secure you,
Like brave gallant Moore of Moore-Hall.
No Giant or Knight e'er quell'd him,
He fills all their Hearts with Alarms;
No Virgin yet ever beheld him,
But wish'd herself clasp'd in his Arms.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS.
SP.L: Let's go to his Dwelling,
With Yelping and Yelling;
We'll move him to Pity,
And tell him, and tell him a sorrowful Ditty.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE, Moore-Hall.
Symphony.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Come, Friends, let's circulate the cheerful Glass;
Let each true Toper toast his favourite Lass.
Sound all your Instruments of Joy, and play:
Let's drink and sing, and pass the Time away.

L.HI: All were Lovers of the Bottle;
Love and Drinking are no Treason.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter GUBBINS, MAUXALINDA, MAR∣GERY, and others.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS.
SP.L: Moore of Moore-Hall!

L.HI: And leave us the Devil a Rag on.

SP.L: [O save, &c.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: Pink of Prowess, and good Breeding,
Let a Virgin's Tears inspire thee;
Let a Maiden's Blushes fire thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Her Looks shoot thro' my Soul, her Eyes strike Fire;
I'm all a Conflagration of Desire.
Fair Maid, I grant whatever you can ask,
The Deed is done, when once you name the Task.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: The Dragon, Sir, the Dragon!

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Say no more,
You soon shall see him weltring in his Gore.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Most mighty Moore! do but this Dra∣gon kill,
All that we have is wholly at your Will.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: The only Bounty I require, is this,
That thou may'st fire me with an ardent Kiss;
That thy soft Hands may 'noint me over Night,
And dress me in the Morning e'er I fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: A forward Lady! she grows fond apace,
But I shall catch her in a proper Place.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Leave her with me; conclude the Dra∣gon dead:
If I don't maul the Dog, I'll lose my Head.

DIV2.STAGE: [All go off but Moore and Margery.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Let my Dearest be near me;

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: I'll ever be near thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: To warm me, to cheer me;

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: To warm thee, to cheer thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: To fire me, inspire me;

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: To fire thee, inspire thee

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: With Kisses and Ale.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Your Fears I'll abolish;

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: This Dragon demolish.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: I'll work him;

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Ay, work him.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: I'll jerk him;

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: [Let my, &c.

DIV2.STAGE: MOORE leads off MARGERY; MAUXA∣LINDA enters, and pulls him back by the Sleeve.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: O Villain! Monster! Devil! Basely base!
How can you dare to look me in the Face?
Did you not swear last Christmas we should marry?
Oh, 'tis enough to make a Maid miscarry!
Witness this Piece of Six-pence, certain Token
Of my true Heart, and your false Promise broken.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: The Devil's in the Woman! What's the Matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: Now you insult me; Time was, you cou'd flatter.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Upon my Soul, I don't know what you mean!

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: Don't you know Margery of Roth'ram-Green?

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Not I, upon my Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: That's a Lie.
What do you think I've neither Ear nor Eye.
Villain! I will believe my Eyes and Ears!
She whom you kiss'd, and call'd ten thousand Dears.
Let my Dearest be near me, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: By Jove! I'm blown. Zounds! how came this about?
However, I'm resolv'd to stand it out.

SP.SPEAKER: To Maux.
SP.L: I only out of Policy was civil;
But, 'faith, I hate her as I hate the Devil.
You're all I value, witness this close Hug,
I'm yours, and only yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: Ah Coaxing Pug!

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: My pretty Mauxy, prithee don't be jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: Dear me! you Men are such bewitching Fellows;
You steal into our Hearts by sly Degrees,
Then make poor Girls believe just what you please.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: By the Beer, as brown as Berry;
By the Cyder and the Perry,
Which so oft has made us merry,

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: But do you really love me?

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: By this Kiss,
By Raptures past, and Hopes of future Bliss.

LG.HEAD: DUETTO.
LG.L: We will out-cooe the Turtle Dove.

DIV1.HEAD: ACT II. SCENE I.

SP.SPEAKER: MARGERY sola.
SP.L: SURE my Stays will burst with sobbing,
And my Heart quite crack with throbbing.
My poor Eyes are red as Ferrets,
And I ha'n't a Grain of Spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: My Madge! my Honey-suckle, in the Dumps!

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Put your Hand here, and feel my Heart how't thumps.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Good lack a day! how great a Palpi∣tation!
Tell me, my Dear! the Cause of this Vexation.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: An ugly Dream has put me in a Fright;
I dreamt the Dragon slew my gentle Knight:
If such a thing should happen unto thee,
O miserable, miserable, Margery!

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Don't fright thy self with Dreams, my Girl, ne'er fear him,
I'll work his Buff, if ever I come near him.
I've such a Suit of spiked Armour bought,
Bears, Lions, Dragons, it will set at nought:
In which, when I'm equip'd, my Madge shall see,
I'll scare the Dragon, not the Dragon me.
But Time grows short, I must a while away.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Make haste, my Dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: My Duck! I will not stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: So Madam! have I found you out at last?
You now shall pay full dear for all that's past.
Were you as fine as e'er wore Silk or Sattin,
I'd beat your Harlot's Brains out with my Pattin,
Before you shall delude a Man of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Who in the Name of Wonder made him thine?

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: D'ye laugh, you Minx! I'll make you change your Note,
Or drive your grinning Grinders down your Throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Lauk, what a monstrous Tail our Cat has got!

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: Nay, if you brave me, then you go to pot.
Come, Bodkin, come! take Mauxalinda's Part,
And stab her hated Rival to the Heart.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter MOORE, takes away the Bodkin.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Why, what the Devil is the Woman doing!

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: To put an End to all your Worship's Wooing.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: 'Tis well I came, before the Whim went further;
Had I stay'd longer, here had sure been Murder.
This cursed Jade has thrown the Girl in Fits.
How do'st, my Dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Frighted out of my Wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: But fear her not, for by her own Con∣fession,
I'll bind her over to the Quarter-Session.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: O give me not up to the Law,
I'd much rather beg upon Crutches;
You never get out of his Clutches.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Come, come, forgive her.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Here my Anger ends.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: And so does mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Why then let's buss and Friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Maux.
SP.L: Oh how easy is a Woman,
How deluding are you Men!
Oh how rare, to find a true Man,
Not so oft as one in ten.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Oh how charming is a Woman,
Form'd to captivate us Men;
Yet so eager to subdue Man,
That for one she covets ten.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Let's reward them as they treat us,
Women prove sincere as Men;
But if they deceive and cheat us,
Let us e'en cheat them again.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Let's reward them as they treat us, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: Now, now, or never save us, valiant Moore!
The Dragon's coming, don't you hear him roar?

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Why let him roar his Heart out, 'tis no matter:
Stand clear, my Friends, this is no Time to chatter.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: Here take your Spear.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: —I scorn Sword, Spear, or Dart;
I'm arm'd compleatly in a valiant Heart.
But first I'll drink, to make me strong and mighty,
Six Quarts of Ale, and one of Aqua Vitae.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS.
SP.L: Fill, fill, fill a mighty Flagon,
Kill, kill, kill this monstrous Dragon.

DIV1.HEAD: ACT III. SCENE I.
DIV1.STAGE: A rural Prospect near the Dragon's Den.
Enter MOORE in Armour, and MARGERY.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: ONe Buss, dear Margery, and then a∣way.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: I cannot go, my Love!

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: You must not stay.
Get up, sweet Wench, get up in yonder Tree,
And there securely you may hear and see.
Come, Mr. Dragon, or by Jove I'll fetch you;
I'll trim your Rascals Jacket, if I catch you.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: Dragon! Dragon! thus I dare thee:
Soon to Atoms thus I'll tear thee;
But regarding where my Dear is,
Then, alas! I feel what Fear is,

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: It is not Strength that always wins;
Good Wit does Strength excel.
Confound the Rascal, how he grins,—
I'll creep into this Well.
SP.STAGE: [Enter Dragon, and goes to the Well, as to drink.

SP.SPEAKER: Dragon.
SP.L: What nasty Dog has got into the Well,
Disturbs my Drink, and makes the Water smell.

LG.HEAD: AIR.
LG.L: I wish I'd known your Tricks before.

DIV1.STAGE: [Moore gets out of the Well, and en∣counters the Dragon.

SP.SPEAKER: Drag.
SP.L: Oh! oh! oh!
The Devil take your Toe.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Oh, my Conqu'ror! how d'ye do?

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Oh, my Charmer! how are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Very well, thank you;

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: I'm so too.
Your Eyes were livid, and your Cheeks were pale;
But now you look as brisk as bottled Ale.
Give me a Buss.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Ah, twenty if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: With all my heart, and twenty after these.

LG.HEAD: DUETT.
LG.L: My sweet Honey suckle, my Joy and Delight,
I'll kiss thee all Day, and I'll hug thee all Night.
My Dearest is made of such excellent Stuff,
I think I shall never have Kissing enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Moore.
SP.L: Now nimbly dance, ye Nymphs and Swains be gay,
The Dragon's dead, and you may safely play.

SP.SPEAKER: Gub.
SP.L: Most mighty Moore, what Wonders hast thou done,
Destroy'd the Dragon, and my Margery won,
The Loves of this brave Knight, and my fair Daughter,
In Roratorios shall be sung hereafter.
Begin your Songs of Joy; begin, begin,
And rend the Welkin with harmonious Din.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS.
SP.L: To gallant Morio,
Of Moore-Hall.
To Margereenia
Of Roth'ram-Greenia,
